• The Mexican government has initiated negotiations for free trade agreements with South Korea, Singapore, and Peru.
• Mexico also intends to commence negotiations for a trade agreement with Australia.

sections.section_name: North American Trade Agreement and the USMCA Agreement
openai_summarised_points: • The 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) is the most significant trade agreement Mexico has signed, notable for the magnitude of reciprocal trade and its comprehensive scope compared to Mexico’s other Free Trade Agreements.

• NAFTA was complemented by two supplementary agreements: the North American Agreement for Environmental Cooperation (NAAEC) and the North American Agreement on Labor Cooperation (NAALC), enhancing environmental and labor standards cooperation among the U.S., Mexico, and Canada.

• An updated version of NAFTA, known as the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), was pending ratification by Canada in early 2020; the United States and Mexico had already ratified the agreement by that time.

• The NAAEC was established in response to environmental concerns that companies might relocate to Mexico or that the U.S. might lower environmental standards without unanimous regulations across the three countries.

• The NAAEC created the North American Commission for Environmental Cooperation (NACEC) to address trade and environmental issues, the North American Development Bank (NADBank) to finance pollution reduction investments, and the Border Environmental Cooperation Commission (BECC).

• NADBank and BECC have financed 36 projects primarily in Mexico’s water sector, providing significant economic and environmental benefits; this environmental cooperation has led NAFTA to be described as the "greenest" trade agreement.
• The NAALC aimed to foster cooperation among the three countries to resolve labor issues and promote collaboration among trade unions and social organizations to improve labor conditions.

• While economists find it difficult to measure the direct impact of NAALC, there has been a general convergence of labor standards in North America; however, NAALC was not intended to, nor has it achieved, convergence in employment levels, productivity, or wage trends.
• NAFTA did not liberalize the movement of people extensively across the three countries but allowed limited immigration of skilled Mexican and Canadian workers to the U.S. under the TN visa status.

• The TN status permits citizens of Mexico and Canada in a wide range of professions, mostly requiring at least a bachelor’s degree, to temporarily work in the U.S. without sponsorship, requiring only a job offer letter.

• On November 30, 2018, Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto, U.S. President Donald Trump, and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau signed the USMCA agreement during the G20 summit in Buenos Aires, Argentina.

• Multiple economic studies, including those by the World Bank and the Institute for International Economics, have concluded that NAFTA positively impacted Mexico by reducing poverty rates and increasing real income salaries, even after the 1994–1995 economic crisis.

• Despite these benefits, NAFTA has not been sufficient or rapid enough to achieve full economic convergence with its partners, substantially reduce poverty, or significantly accelerate economic growth in Mexico.

• The textile industry in Mexico experienced considerable growth due to NAFTA, gaining open access to the U.S. market; Mexican cotton and apparel exports to the U.S. increased from $3 billion in 1995 to $8.4 billion in 2002, peaking at $9.4 billion in 2000.
• The U.S. share of Mexico’s cotton textile market rose from 8 percent in 1995 to 13 percent in 2002, indicating increased integration and export capacity in this sector.
• Analysts suggest that to fully capitalize on NAFTA’s benefits, Mexico should invest more in education, innovation, infrastructure, and agriculture.

• The maquiladora program, which predates NAFTA by nearly three decades (originating in 1965), involves importing raw materials into Mexico tariff-free or at reduced rates for temporary periods (18 months) to manufacture goods using Mexico’s lower labor costs for export.

• Before NAFTA, maquiladora companies importing raw materials globally received preferential tariff rates from Mexico if the finished goods were for export; the U.S. allowed maquiladora goods to enter with tariffs applied only to the value of non-U.S. raw materials, reducing tariffs relative to other countries.
• NAFTA eliminated all tariffs on goods traded between the U.S. and Mexico but increased tariff rates significantly for maquiladora goods sourced from outside the NAFTA region.

• Despite the large volume of trade between Mexico and the United States, trade disputes are relatively few and involve small dollar amounts; these disputes are typically resolved through World Trade Organization (WTO) or NAFTA dispute panels or bilateral negotiations.
• The primary areas of trade friction between Mexico and the U.S. include trucking regulations, sugar, high-fructose corn syrup, and various other agricultural products.
• Mexico has improved its highway infrastructure, particularly dual carriageway highways (marked in red on trade maps), to facilitate trade and exports, especially to the United States.
• Avenida Presidente Masaryk, located in Polanco, is recognized as one of the most expensive streets in the Americas, highlighting the area's economic prominence within Mexico City.
• The buildings situated to the left of the Scotiabank tower are geographically located in Lomas de Chapultepec, not in Polanco, indicating distinct neighborhood boundaries within Mexico City.

• A 2008 research brief published by the World Bank, as part of its Trade Costs and Facilitation Project, analyzed Mexico's potential to significantly enhance trade flows and economic growth through targeted trade facilitation reforms.

• The World Bank study focused on four critical areas for trade facilitation reform in Mexico: port efficiency, customs administration, information technology, and the regulatory environment, including standards.

• The study projected that domestic reforms in these areas could generate overall trade increments valued at approximately $31.8 billion, which corresponds to 22.4 percent of Mexico’s total manufacturing exports during the period 2000–2003.
• On the import side, the projected benefits of trade facilitation reforms were estimated at $17.1 billion, equivalent to 11.2 percent of Mexico’s total imports for the same 2000–2003 period.
• Export increases, notably in textiles, were expected to result primarily from enhancements in port efficiency and improvements in the regulatory environment.
• Exports of transport equipment were projected to experience the largest growth due to improvements in port efficiency, underscoring the importance of port infrastructure for this sector.
• Exports of food and machinery were anticipated to benefit mainly from reforms in the regulatory environment, reflecting the role of standards and regulations in these industries.
• On the import side, improvements in port efficiency were identified as the most significant factor contributing to increased imports overall.
• For imports of transport equipment specifically, enhancements in service sector infrastructure were also considered relatively important alongside port efficiency improvements.

• In 2021, Mexico's largest trading partner by total trade value was the United States, with a trade value of 609.67 billion USD, comprising imports worth 221.31 billion USD and exports totaling 388.36 billion USD, resulting in a positive trade balance of 167.05 billion USD.

• China was Mexico's second-largest trading partner in 2021, with a total trade value of 120.16 billion USD; Mexico imported goods valued at 101.02 billion USD from China and exported 19.14 billion USD, leading to a significant trade deficit of 81.88 billion USD.

• Canada ranked third among Mexico's trade partners in 2021, with a total trade value of 37.93 billion USD, including imports of 11.22 billion USD and exports of 26.71 billion USD, yielding a positive trade balance of 15.49 billion USD.

• South Korea was Mexico's fourth-largest trading partner in 2021, with a total trade value of 26.85 billion USD; imports from South Korea amounted to 18.96 billion USD, exports were 7.89 billion USD, resulting in a trade deficit of 11.08 billion USD.

• Germany held the fifth position in Mexico's trade partnerships in 2021, with a total trade value of 26.50 billion USD, consisting of 17.21 billion USD in imports and 9.29 billion USD in exports, producing a trade deficit of 7.93 billion USD.

• Japan was Mexico's sixth-largest trading partner in 2021, with a total trade value of 22.85 billion USD; imports from Japan were 17.08 billion USD, exports were 5.78 billion USD, and the trade balance showed a deficit of 11.30 billion USD.

• Brazil ranked seventh among Mexico's trade partners in 2021, with a total trade value of 13.49 billion USD, including imports valued at 8.72 billion USD and exports at 4.77 billion USD, resulting in a trade deficit of 3.95 billion USD.

• Malaysia was Mexico's eighth-largest trading partner in 2021, with a total trade value of 12.95 billion USD; imports from Malaysia were 12.39 billion USD, exports were 0.556 billion USD, leading to a trade deficit of 11.83 billion USD.

• Spain ranked ninth in Mexico's trade partnerships in 2021, with a total trade value of 10.10 billion USD, comprising imports of 4.58 billion USD and exports of 5.52 billion USD, resulting in a positive trade balance of 0.935 billion USD.

• India was the tenth-largest trading partner of Mexico in 2021, with a total trade value of 10.06 billion USD; imports from India were 5.92 billion USD, exports were 4.14 billion USD, and the trade balance showed a deficit of 1.78 billion USD.
